quotes.text: You have to give them an experience they didn't know was previously possible.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris

quotes.text: And when you are in that place of doing something that no one has ever done before, that's when you get it.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris

quotes.topic_title: Wise overview: products, scale, and economics
quotes.text: We're looking to solve the problems associated with cross-border money movement, which is that moving money across border is pretty slow. It's actually really expensive, and it can be really hard to do.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Clearly frames the core customer pain points Wise targets, useful as a template for problem-first product positioning.

quotes.topic_title: Wise overview: products, scale, and economics
quotes.text: We solve it with three products, our money transfer product, which is what we started with, our account, which would be like, think of trying to solve the problems of international banking with our account for people, and for businesses. And then finally we've also got an enterprise product where we take the underlying infrastructure that's powered those products that we've built, and embed them in the banks, and products that people use every day,
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Lays out a three-part product strategy (consumer transfer → account → embedded infrastructure) that practitioners can mirror for expansion paths.

quotes.topic_title: Wise overview: products, scale, and economics
quotes.text: So today we're now moving about $12 billion a month, growing between 30 to 40% year on year. We take about 0.65% on average across all our routes as price, and we've been profitable for about more than four years now, with 20% EBITDA margins.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Concrete scale and unit-economics benchmarks showing high growth can coexist with low take-rate and sustained profitability.

quotes.topic_title: Wise overview: products, scale, and economics
quotes.text: But probably the stat I'm most proud of, and the hardest thing to make happen out of all of that was we acquired 70% of the users that found out about Wise last month through word of mouth.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Highlights word-of-mouth as a difficult but high-leverage growth channel worth designing for and measuring explicitly.

quotes.topic_title: Wise overview: products, scale, and economics
quotes.text: so out of a million that joined Wise the first time, 700,000 found out about Wise from a friend.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A vivid, memorable example that quantifies referral-driven acquisition in absolute terms, making the WOM impact tangible.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring word of mouth attribution
quotes.text: We ask customers, is the short answer.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A simple, high-signal methodology for measuring word of mouth that avoids overcomplicating attribution.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring word of mouth attribution
quotes.text: So, we have an attribution model, as you can imagine, and we've had one from the early days, and it overlays all the referrer data and cookie data you have on visits comes to the website.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Describes a practical measurement stack that combines traditional web attribution inputs (referrers/cookies) from the start.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring word of mouth attribution
quotes.text: And then you obviously have the soundtrack stuff, and we sample, and ask customers a set of questions on this, and then overlay that onto the... What turns up in your web tracking as direct traffic to give us a sense of how big that word of mouth number is, and that's what gets us back to the 70% stat.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A concrete approach: sample survey responses and reconcile them with “direct traffic” to estimate word-of-mouth share (including a 70% data point).

quotes.topic_title: Measuring word of mouth attribution
quotes.text: It's actually integrated into the flow. So when we built it originally, we thought it's quite cool, marketing and acquiring customers is part of the product, and we should actually stitch that into the experience seamlessly so that we're able to do this more effectively going forward.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A product-led growth mental model: treat acquisition measurement as a first-class part of the product by embedding questions into onboarding.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring word of mouth attribution
quotes.text: You think there's some fancy ways to understand the stuff, but it's just like, just ask people, they'll tell you how they heard about it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Challenges the assumption that word-of-mouth attribution requires sophisticated tooling—direct user questioning can be enough.

quotes.topic_title: Why Wise prioritized word of mouth early
quotes.text: But taking a step back, think of money as the ultimate commodity.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A mental model for why differentiation and growth channels matter more when your product category is inherently commoditized.

quotes.topic_title: Why Wise prioritized word of mouth early
quotes.text: It's pretty hard to build an expensive business that moves your money somewhere, and it costs a lot, so there's less of it afterwards.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A counterintuitive framing that explains why high-cost acquisition and pricing power are especially difficult in money movement products.

quotes.topic_title: Why Wise prioritized word of mouth early
quotes.text: So building a brand led money transfer business, the brand's got to be pretty damn good, right? You're going to feel pretty special afterwards, in order to have less money afterwards.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Highlights the unusually high bar for brand-led growth when the customer outcome is literally having less money after the transaction.

quotes.topic_title: Why Wise prioritized word of mouth early
quotes.text: So what we're looking for always, but what channels out there are super scalable, and can reach our entire audience, but have an incredibly low distribution cost.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A practical channel-selection framework: prioritize scalable reach with low distribution cost, which naturally points to word of mouth.

quotes.topic_title: Why Wise prioritized word of mouth early
quotes.text: the other challenge with marketing which is unique is because we are lower price, but a superior product, we have less margin to spend on marketing than others in certain paid channels.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Actionable constraint-based insight: if you win on price, you often lose on paid CAC headroom—so you must find more efficient growth loops.

quotes.topic_title: Using NPS as a proxy for recommendation
quotes.text: And the best proxy we found for this was something that most people have heard of, that we actually used quite a lot is net promoter score.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Positions NPS as a practical measurement proxy for word of mouth when direct measurement frameworks were lacking.

quotes.topic_title: Using NPS as a proxy for recommendation
quotes.text: When we overlay the referral data over the NPS survey data, we saw something really interesting.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Introduces a methodology: combining NPS survey responses with referral behavior to uncover what drives recommendation.

quotes.topic_title: Using NPS as a proxy for recommendation
quotes.text: There's very low invite rates at one to six, and not just invite, conversion rates of users that joined for invites. But when we've got people from sixes to this seven and eight group, they doubled the number of people they told. Eight to nine, they doubled again, and nine to 10, they doubled again.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, step-change relationship between NPS bands and referral invites/conversion—useful for prioritizing product work.

quotes.topic_title: Using NPS as a proxy for recommendation
quotes.text: And if you optimize for something like conversion, rate and you move conversion rate with 10%, you kind of get this one-off hit.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Challenges the default growth focus on conversion-rate tweaks by framing them as non-compounding gains.

quotes.topic_title: Using NPS as a proxy for recommendation
quotes.text: But if you move the NPS from 30% to 50%, you increase the viral coefficient of your customer base.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Offers a compounding-growth mental model: improving NPS can increase the customer base’s built-in recommendation rate.

quotes.topic_title: Product pillars: price, speed, ease of use
quotes.text: customers kept telling us the same things, "Make it faster, make it cheaper, make it easier to use."
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable way to distill customer feedback into a small set of product pillars that drive advocacy.

quotes.topic_title: Product pillars: price, speed, ease of use
quotes.text: How do we make this product so good that people will use, it but they'll recommend it?
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A practical guiding question for prioritizing product work around word-of-mouth growth, not just usage.

quotes.topic_title: Product pillars: price, speed, ease of use
quotes.text: if we entered with a product that was priced at say 5.9%, and the alternative was six, customers would use us, but they wouldn't talk about us.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Highlights that small improvements can drive adoption but may be insufficient to trigger word-of-mouth.

quotes.topic_title: Product pillars: price, speed, ease of use
quotes.text: We only got the advocacy when we were eight to 10 times cheaper. That's when people started talking about it.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A concrete threshold example showing that advocacy often requires a dramatic, not marginal, advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Product pillars: price, speed, ease of use
quotes.text: you just create these pillars, essentially, of like, "We're going to work on these three things. These are the three levers to help grow word of mouth for this product."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A lightweight methodology: define a few core levers and align teams/KPIs to systematically drive WOM.

quotes.topic_title: Trust: hard to market, easier via friends
quotes.text: what people trust is their friends. And this really was way stronger a trust signal than anything I could put on a landing page.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A practical mental model for trust-building: prioritize friend-to-friend recommendation over on-site trust badges and messaging.

quotes.topic_title: Trust: hard to market, easier via friends
quotes.text: trust in isolation is a really hard problem to solve. You need to get under the skin of what it means. People don't think my money is safe. "I don't know if this company is reputable," to unpick each of these problems and figure out systemically how to solve them.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A framework for diagnosing “trust” by decomposing it into specific user fears and solving them systematically rather than treating trust as a single lever.

quotes.topic_title: Trust: hard to market, easier via friends
quotes.text: there's a massive shortcut, which is if you deliver your customers a good experience, then figure out, how do you make it so good they'll recommend it? Then that kind of shortcut a lot of really hard trust problems.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Actionable growth advice: focus on making the experience recommendation-worthy as a shortcut to overcoming trust barriers.

quotes.topic_title: Trust: hard to market, easier via friends
quotes.text: No, it was literally get more people using it, and they'll share with their friends.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A blunt, execution-oriented approach to building trust via word of mouth: drive usage first, and sharing follows.

quotes.topic_title: Blowing users’ socks off to earn 9–10 NPS
quotes.text: So my learning on this is you've got to work really hard to get recommendation. So, to get a nine or a 10, so our NPS is 70%, so it's really, really high.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Highlights that true recommendation (9–10 NPS) requires significant effort and anchors it with a concrete benchmark (Wise at ~70).

quotes.topic_title: Blowing users’ socks off to earn 9–10 NPS
quotes.text: But, what I've found is when you build a product, most founders, and most teams kind of stop when it works.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A sharp diagnosis of a common product trap—shipping functional is not enough to earn word-of-mouth.

quotes.topic_title: Blowing users’ socks off to earn 9–10 NPS
quotes.text: But to get to recommendation, you're going to blow your users' socks off, and the phrase we use is, you have to give them an experience they didn't know was previously possible.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A memorable framework for driving word of mouth: create a step-change experience users didn’t realize could exist.

quotes.topic_title: Blowing users’ socks off to earn 9–10 NPS
quotes.text: And to put that in context, that means figuring out how to move money instantly. That means figuring out how to drop the price all the way from six all the way down to 0.35.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Turns the “blow their socks off” bar into concrete product levers (speed and price) with a specific example of magnitude.

quotes.topic_title: Blowing users’ socks off to earn 9–10 NPS
quotes.text: Yeah, it was talking to customers, and looking at the survey results, and then through that, in many different ways, price will come up, speed will come up, ease of use will come up, and they kind of aggregate up to that.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A practical method for identifying what to improve: combine customer conversations with survey analysis to find recurring drivers.

quotes.topic_title: Common WOM mistake: shortcuts vs 10x product
quotes.text: But it doesn't grow like a hockey stick. It doesn't grow like a hockey stick because we haven't fundamentally changed the problems in moving money internationally.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Highlights that quick market-entry shortcuts may get initial users but won’t generate breakout WOM unless you solve the core problem materially better.

quotes.topic_title: Common WOM mistake: shortcuts vs 10x product
quotes.text: So, got this mantra, you've got to build a 10x better product than what's there. And if it's 10x product better, basically it doesn't exist already.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A crisp standard for WOM-driven growth: aim for an order-of-magnitude improvement that likely requires building something new, not assembling existing parts.

quotes.topic_title: Common WOM mistake: shortcuts vs 10x product
quotes.text: So it comes from a very logical place, how do I get users quickly? I can take a shortcut in doing this, but that, you kind of realize is wasted effort.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Warns that optimizing for speed-to-launch can be a trap if it diverts effort from the changes needed to drive compounding WOM.

quotes.topic_title: Common WOM mistake: shortcuts vs 10x product
quotes.text: Like what is the theoretical minimum cost for moving money into a market? What is the theoretical maximum speed?
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Introduces a “theoretical limits” method for product design—define the true floor/ceiling first, then build toward that target.

quotes.topic_title: Common WOM mistake: shortcuts vs 10x product
quotes.text: And instead of incrementally going, doing a jump to make it a little better, a little better, a little better, you can never get there. How do we take two years, and end up there?
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Advocates making bigger, longer-horizon bets rather than incremental iteration when the goal is a 10x leap that drives WOM.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb parallels: working backward from the ideal
quotes.text: The ideal was, there's this whole process where the founders hired this storyboard artist from Pixar to draw out the ideal experience of a host and a guest.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Illustrates a concrete method (storyboarding the end-to-end journey) for defining an ideal-state product experience.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb parallels: working backward from the ideal
quotes.text: So, this became essentially the vision of the company is let's make each of these frames, these key moments of a journey for hosting a guest as incredible as possible.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical strategy model: break the experience into key moments and systematically improve each one.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb parallels: working backward from the ideal
quotes.text: And turned out 50% of the time the guest was ignored, or rejected, and the host was just like, "Nah, no thank you."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A sharp data point showing how hidden friction in a core flow can be massive—and worth redesigning.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb parallels: working backward from the ideal
quotes.text: And so that was a huge transition that I worked on, and that came from, if we were to start Airbnb again today, or if someone were to disrupt Airbnb, what would it look like?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A disruptive-restart thought experiment practitioners can use to escape incrementalism and find step-change improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb parallels: working backward from the ideal
quotes.text: We launched at 0.5%, and now we're down to about 0.35%.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A concrete performance outcome that signals step-change improvement on pricing over time.

quotes.topic_title: How Wise drove prices down profitably
quotes.text: So, every month you get bills, and they turn up in your P&L, but every single bill we got, we allocated the cost back to the customer, or the transaction that generated it. And then we add our margin on top, and that's our price.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A concrete cost-allocation-to-pricing methodology that makes unit economics explicit and actionable at the transaction level.

quotes.topic_title: How Wise drove prices down profitably
quotes.text: And when you look at this and you analyze it, you'll find obviously there are 20% of customers generating 80% of the costs. And what you do is you get those 20%, you give them a raise, because they should cover their costs, and you drop the price to everyone else.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A counterintuitive pricing move—raise prices on the costliest minority to lower prices for the majority—grounded in Pareto cost distribution.

quotes.topic_title: How Wise drove prices down profitably
quotes.text: Totally, but it's down to this level of, if an Australian customer calls up asking, "Where is my transfer?" That cost of that call gets allocated back to the AUD/GBP route. If a Brazilian business needs like 20 documents in order to be verified before we can give them an account, the cost of verifying check those customers goes back there, so that at a very atomic level starts happening.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Shows how to operationalize “true cost” pricing with granular attribution by route/segment using specific, real-world examples.

quotes.topic_title: How Wise drove prices down profitably
quotes.text: So, what are the costs? So if you look at our P&L, there's just three costs at transaction level. You've got people costs, you've got the cost of risk, realized risk, and then you've got partner fees.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A simple decomposition of transaction economics into three buckets that teams can target systematically for cost reduction.

quotes.topic_title: How Wise drove prices down profitably
quotes.text: And so if you've got this mission of moving the world's money for almost nothing, or zero, as close to zero as you can, you've got to invest as much of your cashflow in engineering to try to engineer away these three problems.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Actionable strategic guidance: reinvest cashflow into engineering to structurally remove the core cost drivers rather than just optimizing pricing.

quotes.topic_title: Singapore EKYC story: 10x convenience and advocacy
quotes.text: But I like to think of that as the cost of poor quality.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Reframes customer support and ops headcount as a quality/automation problem, not a fixed cost of doing business.

quotes.topic_title: Singapore EKYC story: 10x convenience and advocacy
quotes.text: But come back to your question, how do you step change that? How do you do a 10x better experience?
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Introduces a “step change/10x” bar for experience improvements rather than incremental optimization.

quotes.topic_title: Singapore EKYC story: 10x convenience and advocacy
quotes.text: They gave us the license, but they said, "You have to physically meet every single customer."
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Concrete example of a regulatory constraint that forces an expensive, high-friction onboarding process.

quotes.topic_title: Singapore EKYC story: 10x convenience and advocacy
quotes.text: But the magic was we got the customers not to complain to us, but to complain to the government.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Counterintuitive WOM tactic: channel customer frustration toward the true bottleneck (regulation) to unlock systemic change.

quotes.topic_title: Singapore EKYC story: 10x convenience and advocacy
quotes.text: And that's what I call a 10x better experience than anyone else in the market, and that led to advocacy and word of mouth off the back of it.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Connects a dramatically improved onboarding experience directly to advocacy and word-of-mouth growth.

quotes.topic_title: Mission-driven sharing and customer-led growth flywheel
quotes.text: The way I think about this is that there are the rational reasons why people recommend, which we've covered. But there's these emotional ones as well. Softer ones people would call brand. I prefer to call it on the mission.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A practical mental model for word-of-mouth: separate rational product drivers from emotional mission-driven drivers.

quotes.topic_title: Mission-driven sharing and customer-led growth flywheel
quotes.text: We got more new customers from that email being forwarded around than any other kind of marketing. And I show this when I talk at conferences. This email broke all the rules of marketing. It didn't have a call to action, it didn't have a button to sign up, it didn't have anything in it, but people just forwarded it around saying, "You should check out Wise."
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A counterintuitive growth example: mission authenticity can outperform traditional marketing mechanics like CTAs.

quotes.topic_title: Mission-driven sharing and customer-led growth flywheel
quotes.text: So somehow we emotionally connect our cause, and then I see going, taking a step back, getting 10x better on price is through our customers helping us do it, which gets us even cheaper, which then brings more customers, that then creates this flywheel that's spins around.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Describes a customer-led growth flywheel where mission-driven advocacy enables cost improvements that compound acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: Mission-driven sharing and customer-led growth flywheel
quotes.text: So, taking a step back, where every business I've ever worked in, it's always got these two lists, a list of things to do for your customers, and then it's got a list of things to do to make money. And you generally do everything you need to do to make money, and you do two things with the customer list, and you go, "Customer led business." And then, neat thing about wise, and I'm pretty sure you'll see the same thing on Airbnb is, we just had one list, which is this list of things that you need to do to make customers happy, and it's prioritized by impact on the really hard things. And if you do these really hard things, they have an incredible impact for customers, but hence on your growth, and on your shareholder value.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A prioritization methodology: collapse “customer” and “money” roadmaps into one impact-ranked list tied to hard customer outcomes that drive growth.

quotes.topic_title: Conviction over constant A/B testing
quotes.text: So there's one kind of strategic bet at the heart of Wise. That is if we have the lowest cost platform, and it's really fast, and really high quality, the world's volume will switch to us.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A clear strategic framework: pick a small set of core levers (cost, speed, quality) and commit to them as the growth engine rather than optimizing locally.

quotes.topic_title: Conviction over constant A/B testing
quotes.text: And just marginally getting there step by step by step, and trying to track the incremental return is actually slower.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A contrarian point that excessive incrementalism and ROI-tracking can slow progress versus making bigger conviction-led moves.

quotes.topic_title: Conviction over constant A/B testing
quotes.text: So this is a great line for use internally, I'm sure you've heard it, "You can't split test your way to love."
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why experimentation alone can’t substitute for building products customers truly care about.

quotes.topic_title: Conviction over constant A/B testing
quotes.text: I said, "You're not going to do this. I'm going to give you three weeks and you're going to pick one thing to change, but you're going to go talk to people, and get quantitative insights, and build your own gut feel around what matters, and then launch it, and submit, test it, and see if it works."
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Actionable operating advice: force focus, use customer conversations + quantitative insight to build conviction, then ship and validate.

quotes.topic_title: Conviction over constant A/B testing
quotes.text: But this thing of building conviction on what matters, and I watch how teams slowly build this and you need the data there to make sure it doesn't become a hubris, right? That enables you to make much bigger changes than just experimenting away, and it forces you to get clear on what actually is the problem to solve here, and how do I solve it really, really well?
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A methodology for balancing conviction with measurement: use data as a guardrail against hubris while enabling bigger, clearer bets.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Contemporary art has outpaced the S&P 500 by 136% over the last 27 years.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor message (Masterworks)
quotes.context: A concrete comparative performance data point that frames art as a potentially high-performing asset class versus public equities.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Citibank and Deloitte have reported that contemporary art has performed well as an inflation hedge, and the appreciation is almost entirely uncorrelated to other financial markets.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor message (Masterworks)
quotes.context: Highlights a diversification and inflation-hedging thesis practitioners can use when thinking about portfolio construction.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: However, there's never been a way to invest in it practically without spending millions.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor message (Masterworks)
quotes.context: A succinct articulation of the historical barrier to entry that explains why a new product category (fractional access) can unlock demand.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: In fact, Masterworks latest exit just last month delivered another double-digit annualized net return for their investors
quotes.speaker: Sponsor message (Masterworks)
quotes.context: A specific recent example of outcomes that makes the investment claim more tangible and time-bound.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: As with any investment, past performance is not indicative of future performance. Investing involves risk.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor message (Masterworks)
quotes.context: A practical risk reminder that counters performance marketing and reinforces disciplined decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Trusting teams, bold bets, and SEO example
quotes.text: I think that there's an interesting correlation between products that grow through word of mouth, and less need to experiment with everything.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive idea that strong word-of-mouth products may rely less on constant experimentation and more on product intuition.

quotes.topic_title: Trusting teams, bold bets, and SEO example
quotes.text: But then it becomes difficult as you grow. You have to delegate, and then you have to trust people on your team making the right decisions.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames the scaling challenge as a leadership/trust problem: delegation requires empowering teams to make calls without perfect certainty.

quotes.topic_title: Trusting teams, bold bets, and SEO example
quotes.text: So, as I say, almost everything we do, we have some way of understanding the impact. So, that's always there.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: A practical operating principle: even bold bets should be paired with measurement so teams can learn and course-correct.

quotes.topic_title: Trusting teams, bold bets, and SEO example
quotes.text: We definitely have things where the team does something where Kristo or I will say, "This is just crazy. There's no way they're going to use this." And then we have a culture where people are encouraged to do these things, if they believe in it.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Describes a culture mechanism for innovation: leaders can disagree, but teams are still empowered to ship if they have conviction.

quotes.topic_title: Trusting teams, bold bets, and SEO example
quotes.text: And the founder, and the SEO team went out and built it, and it's huge now, in terms of visits.
quotes.speaker: Nilan Peiris
quotes.context: Concrete example of an SEO-led product bet (currency converter) that drove significant traffic despite initial leadership skepticism.
